pli-tv-kd1:1.0.1: 1. The account with the Bodhi tree
pli-tv-kd1:1.0.2: Homage to the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One
pli-tv-kd1:1.1.1: Soon after his awakening, the Buddha was staying at Uruvelā on the bank of the river Nerañjara at the foot of a Bodhi tree.
pli-tv-kd1:1.1.2: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.1: Then, in the first part of the night, the Buddha reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.2: “Ignorance is the condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are the condition for consciousness; consciousness is the condition for name and form; name and form are the condition for the six sense spheres; the six sense spheres are the condition for contact; contact is the condition for feeling; feeling is the condition for craving; craving is the condition for grasping; grasping is the condition for existence; existence is the condition for birth; birth is the condition for old age and death, for grief, sorrow, pain, aversion, and distress to come to be.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.3: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.4: But with the complete fading away and end of ignorance comes the end of intentional activities; with the end of intentional activities comes the end of consciousness; with the end of consciousness comes the end of name and form; with the end of name and form comes the end of the six sense spheres; with the end of the six sense spheres comes the end of contact; with the end of contact comes the end of feeling; with the end of feeling comes the end of craving; with the end of craving comes the end of grasping; with the end of grasping comes the end of existence; with the end of existence comes the end of birth; with the end of birth comes the end of old age and death, and the end of sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and distress.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.5: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.1: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.3: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.4: Then all his doubts are dispelled,
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.5: Since he understands the natural order and its conditions.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.1: In the middle part of the night, the Buddha again reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.2: “Ignorance is the condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are the condition for consciousness; consciousness is the condition for name and form …
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.3: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering. …
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.4: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.1: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.3: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.4: Then all his doubts are dispelled,
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.5: Since he’s understood the end of the conditions.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.1: In the last part of the night, the Buddha again reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.2: “Ignorance is the condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are the condition for consciousness; consciousness is the condition for name and form …
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.3: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering. …
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.4: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.1: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.3: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.4: He defeats the army of the Lord of Death,
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.5: Like the sun beaming in the sky.”
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.6: The account with the Bodhi tree is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:2.1.0: 2. The account with the goatherd’s banyan tree
pli-tv-kd1:2.1.1: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the Bodhi tree to a goatherd’s banyan tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:2.2.1: Then a conceited brahmin went up to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd1:2.2.5: “Good Gotama, how is one a brahmin? What are the qualities that make one a brahmin?”
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.1: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.2: “The brahmin who has shut out bad qualities,
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.3: Who is humble, free from flaws, and self-controlled,
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.4: Who has reached final knowledge and has fulfilled the spiritual life—
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.5: He may rightly proclaim himself a brahmin,
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.6: Having no conceit about anything in the world.”
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.7: The account with the goatherd’s banyan tree is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:3.1.0: 3. The account with the powderpuff tree
pli-tv-kd1:3.1.1: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the goatherd’s banyan tree to a powderpuff tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.1: Just then an unseasonal storm was approaching, bringing seven days of rain, cold winds, and clouds.
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.2: Mucalinda, the dragon king, came out from his abode. He encircled the body of the Buddha with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head, thinking,
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.3: “May the Buddha not be hot or cold, nor be bothered by horseflies or mosquitoes, by the wind or the burning sun, or by creeping animals or insects.”
pli-tv-kd1:3.3.1: After seven days, when he knew the sky was clear, Mucalinda unraveled his coils from the Buddha’s body and transformed himself into a young brahmin. He then stood in front of the Buddha, raising his joined palms in veneration.
pli-tv-kd1:3.3.2: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.2: Who sees the Teaching that they have learned.
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.3: Kindness to the world is happiness,
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.4: For one who’s harmless to living beings.
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.5: Dispassion for the world is happiness,
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.8: This, indeed, is the highest bliss.”
pli-tv-kd1:3.4.9: The account with the powderpuff tree is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:4.1.0: 4. The account with the ape-flower tree
pli-tv-kd1:4.1.1: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the powderpuff tree to an ape-flower tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.1: Just then the merchants Tapussa and Bhallika were traveling from Ukkala to that area.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.2: Then a god who was a former relative of theirs said to them,
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.3: “Sirs, a Buddha who has just attained awakening is staying at the foot of an ape-flower tree.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.4: Go to that Buddha and offer him baked goods and honey.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.5: That will be for your benefit and happiness for a long time.”
pli-tv-kd1:4.3.1: And they took baked goods and honey and went to the Buddha. They bowed down
pli-tv-kd1:4.3.3: “Venerable Sir, please accept the baked goods and honey from us. That will be for our benefit and happiness for a long time.”
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.3: In what should I receive the baked goods and honey?”
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.4: Then, reading the mind of the Buddha, the four great kings offered him four crystal bowls from the four directions, saying,
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.5: “Here, Sir, please receive the baked goods and honey in these.”
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.6: After receiving the baked goods and honey in one of the valuable crystal bowls, the Buddha ate them.
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.1: When Tapussa and Bhallika knew that the Buddha had finished his meal, they bowed down with their head at his feet, and said,
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.2: “Sir, we go for refuge to the Buddha and the Teaching. Please accept us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.3: By means of the double refuge, they became the first lay followers in the world.
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.4: The account with the ape-flower tree is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:5.1.0: 5. The account of the supreme being’s request
pli-tv-kd1:5.1.1: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the ape-flower tree to a goatherd’s banyan tree,
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.1: Then, while reflecting in private, the Buddha thought this:
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.2: “I have discovered this profound truth, so hard to see, so hard to comprehend. It’s peaceful and sublime, subtle, beyond the intellect, and knowable only to the wise.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.3: But human beings delight in holding on, find pleasure in holding on, rejoice in holding on,
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.4: and because of that it’s hard for them to see causal relationships, dependent origination.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.5: This too is very hard for them to see: the stilling of all intentional activities, the giving up of all ownership, the stopping of craving, fading away, ending, extinguishment.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.6: If I were to teach this truth, others would not understand, and that would be wearying and troublesome for me.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.1: And spontaneously, these verses never heard before occurred to the Buddha:
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.3: There’s no point in making it known.
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.4: For those overcome by sensual desire and ill will,
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.5: This truth is hard to understand.
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.6: Those who are excited by sensual desire,
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.7: Obstructed by a mass of darkness,
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.8: Won’t see what goes against the stream,
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.9: What’s subtle and refined, profound and hard to see.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.1: When the Buddha reflected like this, he inclined to inactivity, not to teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.2: Just then the supreme being Sahampati read the mind of the Buddha. He thought,
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.3: “The world is lost; it’s perished!—for the Buddha, perfected and fully awakened, inclines to inaction, not to teaching.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.5.1: Then, just as a strong man might bend or stretch his arm, Sahampati disappeared from the world of supreme beings and appeared in front of the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd1:5.6.1: He put his upper robe over one shoulder, placed his right knee on the ground, raised his joined palms, and said,
pli-tv-kd1:5.6.3: There are beings with little dust in their eyes who are ruined because of not hearing the Teaching. There will be those who understand.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.1: This is what Sahampati said, and he added:
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.3: An impure teaching appeared, conceived by defiled people.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.4: Open this door to the deathless!
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.5: Let them hear the Teaching, discovered by the Pure One.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.6: Just as one standing on a rocky mountain top
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.7: Would see the people all around,
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.9: Ascend the temple of the Truth.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.10: Being rid of sorrow, look upon the people,
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.11: Sunk in grief, overcome by birth and old age.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.13: Leader of travelers, wander the world without obligation.
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.15: There will be those who understand.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.8.1: Twice the Buddha repeated to Sahampati what he had thought,
pli-tv-kd1:5.9.1: and on both occasions Sahampati repeated his request.
pli-tv-kd1:5.10.1: The Buddha understood the request of that supreme being. Then, with the eye of a Buddha, he surveyed the world out of compassion for sentient beings.
pli-tv-kd1:5.11.1: He saw beings with little dust in their eyes and with much dust in their eyes, with sharp faculties and with dull faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and difficult to teach. He even saw some who regarded the next world as dangerous and to be avoided, while others did not.
pli-tv-kd1:5.11.2: It was just like blue, red, and white lotuses, sprouted and grown in a lotus pond: some remain submerged in the water without rising out of it, others reach the surface of the water, while others still rise out of the water without being touched by it.
pli-tv-kd1:5.12.1: When he had seen this, the Buddha replied to Sahampati in verse:
pli-tv-kd1:5.12.2: “Open to them are the doors to the deathless!
pli-tv-kd1:5.12.3: May those who hear release their faith.
pli-tv-kd1:5.12.5: I did not speak the sublime and subtle Truth.”
pli-tv-kd1:5.13.2: “The Buddha has consented to teach.” He bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and disappeared right there.
pli-tv-kd1:5.13.3: The account of the supreme being’s request is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:6.1.5: “Ālāra Kālāma is wise and competent, and has for a long time had little dust in his eyes.
pli-tv-kd1:6.1.6: Let me teach him first. He will understand it quickly.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.2.1: But an invisible god informed the Buddha, “Sir, Ālāra Kālāma died seven days ago,”
pli-tv-kd1:6.2.2: and the Buddha also knew this for himself.
pli-tv-kd1:6.2.5: If he had heard this Teaching, he would have understood it quickly.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.3.3: Who will understand this Teaching quickly?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.3.5: “Udaka Rāmaputta is wise and competent, and has for a long time had little dust in his eyes.
pli-tv-kd1:6.3.6: Let me teach him first. He will understand it quickly.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.4.1: But an invisible god informed the Buddha, “Sir, Udaka Rāmaputta died last night,”
pli-tv-kd1:6.4.2: and the Buddha also knew this for himself.
pli-tv-kd1:6.4.5: If he had heard this Teaching, he would have understood it quickly.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.5.3: Who will understand this Teaching quickly?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.5.5: “The group of five monks who supported me while I was striving were of great service to me.
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.3: But where are they staying now?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.4: With his superhuman and purified clairvoyance, the Buddha saw that the group of five monks were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.5: Then, after staying at Uruvelā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Benares.
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.1: The Ājīvaka ascetic Upaka saw the Buddha traveling between Gayā and the place of awakening. He said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.2: “Sir, your senses are clear and your skin is pure and bright.
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.3: In whose name have you gone forth?
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.5: or whose teaching do you follow?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.1: The Buddha replied to Upaka in verse:
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.2: “I’m the victor, the knower of all.
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.3: Abandoning all, I’m not soiled by anything.
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.4: Through my own insight, I’m freed by the ending of craving—
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.5: So who should I refer to as a teacher?
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.8: In the world with its gods,
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.14: I’m going to the city of Kāsi,
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.15: To set rolling the wheel of the Teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.16: In this world immersed in darkness,
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.17: I’ll beat the drum of the deathless.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.9.1: “According to your own claim you must be a universal conqueror.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.9.3: Those who have ended the corruptions.
pli-tv-kd1:6.9.4: I have conquered all bad traits—
pli-tv-kd1:6.9.6: Saying, “May it be so,” Upaka shook his head, chose the wrong path, and left.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.1: The Buddha continued wandering toward the deer park at Isipatana near Benares. When he eventually arrived, he went to the group of five monks.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.3: the group of five made an agreement with one another:
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.4: “Here comes the ascetic Gotama, who has given up his striving and returned to a life of indulgence.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.5: We shouldn’t bow down to him, stand up for him, or receive his bowl and robe,
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.6: but we should prepare a seat. If he wishes, he may sit down.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.1: But as the Buddha approached, the group of five monks was unable to keep their agreement.
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.2: One went to meet him to receive his bowl and robe, another prepared a seat, another set out water for washing the feet, yet another set out a foot stool, and the last one put out a foot scraper.
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.3: The Buddha sat down on the prepared seat
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.5: But they still addressed him by name and as “friend”.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.1: The Buddha said to the group of five monks,
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.2: “Monks, don’t address the Buddha by name or as ‘friend’.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.3: Listen, I’m perfected and fully awakened. I have discovered the deathless. I will instruct you and teach you the Truth.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.5: in this very life you will soon realize with your own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.6: for which gentlemen rightly go forth into homelessness.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.13.2: “Friend Gotama, by practicing extreme austerities you didn’t gain any superhuman quality, any distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of noble ones. Since you have given up your striving and returned to a life of indulgence, how could you now have achieved any of this?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.14.2: “I haven’t given up striving and returned to a life of indulgence,”
pli-tv-kd1:6.14.3: and he repeated what he had said before.
pli-tv-kd1:6.15.1: A second time the group of five monks repeated their question
pli-tv-kd1:6.15.2: and a second time the Buddha repeated his reply.
pli-tv-kd1:6.15.3: A third time they repeated their question,
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.2: “Have you ever heard me speak like this?”
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.4: “Then listen. I’m perfected and fully awakened. I have discovered the deathless. I will instruct you and teach you the Truth.
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.6: in this very life you will soon realize with your own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.7: for which gentlemen rightly go forth into homelessness.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.8: The Buddha was able to persuade the group of five monks.
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.9: They then listened to the Buddha, paid careful attention, and applied their minds to understand.
pli-tv-kd1:6.17.2: “There are these two opposites that should not be pursued by one who has gone forth.
pli-tv-kd1:6.17.4: One is the devotion to worldly pleasures, which is inferior, crude, common, ignoble, and unbeneficial. The other is the devotion to self-torment, which is painful, ignoble, and unbeneficial.
pli-tv-kd1:6.17.5: By avoiding these opposites, I have awakened to the middle path, which produces vision and knowledge, which leads to peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
pli-tv-kd1:6.18.1: And what, monks, is that middle path?
pli-tv-kd1:6.18.2: It’s just this noble eightfold path,
pli-tv-kd1:6.18.3: that is, right view, right aim, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right stillness.
pli-tv-kd1:6.19.1: And this is noble truth of suffering:
pli-tv-kd1:6.19.2: birth is suffering, old age is suffering, sickness is suffering, death is suffering, association with what is disliked is suffering, separation from what is liked is suffering, not getting what you want is suffering.
pli-tv-kd1:6.19.3: In brief, the five aspects of existence affected by grasping are suffering.
pli-tv-kd1:6.20.1: And this is noble truth of the origin of suffering:
pli-tv-kd1:6.20.2: the craving that leads to rebirth, that comes with delight and sensual desire, ever delighting in this and that,
pli-tv-kd1:6.20.3: that is, craving for worldly pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for non-existence.
pli-tv-kd1:6.21.1: And this is noble truth of the end of suffering:
pli-tv-kd1:6.21.2: the full fading away and ending of that very craving; giving it up, relinquishing it, releasing it, letting it go.
pli-tv-kd1:6.22.1: And this is noble truth of the path leading to the end of suffering:
pli-tv-kd1:6.22.3: that is, right view, right aim, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right stillness.

pli-tv-kd1:6.27.1: So long as I had not fully purified my knowledge and vision according to reality of these four noble truths with their three stages and twelve characteristics, I didn’t claim the supreme full awakening in this world with its gods, lords of death, and supreme beings, in this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and people.
pli-tv-kd1:6.28.1: But when I had fully purified my knowledge and vision according to reality of these four noble truths with their three stages and twelve characteristics, then I did claim the supreme full awakening in this world with its gods, lords of death, and supreme beings, in this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and people.
pli-tv-kd1:6.29.1: And knowledge and vision arose in me:
pli-tv-kd1:6.29.2: ‘My freedom is unshakable, this is my last birth, now there is no further rebirth.’”
pli-tv-kd1:6.29.3: This is what the Buddha said. The monks from the group of five were pleased and they rejoiced in the Buddha’s exposition.
pli-tv-kd1:6.29.4: And while this exposition was being spoken, Venerable Koṇḍañña experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:
pli-tv-kd1:6.29.5: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.1: When the Buddha had set rolling the wheel of the Teaching, the earth gods cried out,
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.2: “At Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has set rolling the supreme wheel of the Teaching. It can’t be stopped by any monastic, brahmin, god, lord of death, supreme being, or anyone in the world.”
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.3: Hearing the earth gods, the gods of the four great kings cried out …
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.4: Hearing the gods of the four great kings, the gods of the Thirty-three cried out …

pli-tv-kd1:14.1.0: 11. The account of the fine group of people
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Benares for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Uruvelā.
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.2: At a certain point he left the road, entered a forest grove, and sat down at the foot of a tree.
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.3: Just then a fine group of thirty friends and their wives were enjoying themselves in that forest grove.
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.4: Because one of them did not have a wife,
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.5: they had brought him a sex worker.
pli-tv-kd1:14.1.6: While they were all carelessly enjoying themselves, that sex worker took that man’s possessions and ran away.
pli-tv-kd1:14.2.1: To help their friend, they all went searching for that woman. And as they walked about that forest grove, they saw the Buddha seated at the foot of a tree.
pli-tv-kd1:14.2.3: “Sir, have you seen a woman by any chance?”
pli-tv-kd1:14.2.4: “But, young men, why look for a woman?”

pli-tv-kd1:14.3.2: that you search for a woman, or that you search for yourselves?”
pli-tv-kd1:14.3.3: “It’s better that we search for ourselves.”
pli-tv-kd1:14.3.4: “Well then, sit down, and I’ll give you a teaching.”
pli-tv-kd1:14.3.5: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” those friends bowed to the Buddha and sat down.
pli-tv-kd1:14.4.1: The Buddha then gave them a progressive talk—

pli-tv-kd1:14.4.3: When the Buddha knew that their minds were ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path.

pli-tv-kd1:25.1.0: 15. Discussion of the proper conduct toward the preceptor
pli-tv-kd1:25.1.1: At that time the monks did not have preceptors or teachers, and as a result they were not being instructed. When walking for almsfood, they were shabbily dressed and improper in appearance.
pli-tv-kd1:25.1.2: While people were eating, they held out their almsbowls to receive leftovers, even right over their food, whether it was cooked or fresh food, delicacies or drinks.
pli-tv-kd1:25.1.3: They ate bean curry and rice that they themselves had asked for,
pli-tv-kd1:25.1.4: and they were noisy in the dining hall.
pli-tv-kd1:25.2.2: “How can the Sakyan monastics act like this?
pli-tv-kd1:25.2.5: They are just like brahmins at a brahminical meal!”
pli-tv-kd1:25.3.1: The monks heard the complaints of those people.
pli-tv-kd1:25.3.2: The monks of few desires, who had a sense of conscience, and who were contented, afraid of wrongdoing, and fond of the training, complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd1:25.4.3: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:25.4.4: “Is it true, monks, that monks act like this?”
pli-tv-kd1:25.5.2: “It’s not suitable for those foolish men, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of a monastic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
pli-tv-kd1:25.5.3: How can they act like this?
pli-tv-kd1:25.5.5: and cause some to lose it.”
pli-tv-kd1:25.6.1: Then the Buddha spoke in many ways in dispraise of being difficult to support and maintain, in dispraise of great desires, discontent, socializing, and laziness; but he spoke in many ways in praise of being easy to support and maintain, of fewness of wishes, contentment, self-effacement, ascetic practices, serenity, reduction in things, and being energetic. After giving a teaching on what is right and proper, he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:25.6.3: The preceptor should think of his student as a son and the student his preceptor as a father.
pli-tv-kd1:25.6.4: In this way they will respect, esteem, and be considerate toward each other, and they will grow and reach greatness on this spiritual path.
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.1: A preceptor should be chosen like this.
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.2: After putting his upper robe over one shoulder, a student should pay respect at the feet of the potential preceptor. He should then squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say,
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.4: And he should repeat this a second
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.6: If the other conveys the following by body, by speech, or by body and speech: ‘Yes;’ ‘No problem;’ ‘It’s suitable;’ ‘It’s appropriate;’ or, ‘Carry on with inspiration’—then a preceptor has been chosen.
pli-tv-kd1:25.7.7: If the other doesn’t convey this by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then a preceptor hasn’t been chosen.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.1: “A student should conduct himself properly toward his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.3: Having gotten up at the appropriate time, the student should remove his sandals and put his upper robe over one shoulder. He should then give his preceptor a tooth cleaner and water for rinsing the mouth, and he should prepare a seat for him.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.4: If there is rice porridge, he should wash a vessel and bring the rice porridge to his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.5: When the preceptor has drunk the rice porridge, the student should give him water and receive the vessel. Holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.6: When the preceptor has gotten up, the student should put away the seat.
pli-tv-kd1:25.8.7: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.9.1: If the preceptor wants to enter the village, the student should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return. He should give him a belt. He should put the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, and then give them to him. He should wash his preceptor’s bowl and give it to him while wet.
pli-tv-kd1:25.9.2: If the preceptor wants an attendant, the student should put on his sarong evenly all around, covering the navel and the knees. He should put on a belt. Putting the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, he should put them on and fasten the toggle. He should wash his bowl, bring it along, and be his preceptor’s attendant.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.1: He shouldn’t walk too far behind his preceptor or too close to him. He should receive the contents of his bowl.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.2: He shouldn’t interrupt his preceptor when he’s speaking.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.3: But if the preceptor’s speech is bordering on an offense, he should stop him.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.4: When returning, the student should go first to prepare a seat and to set out a foot stool, a foot scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should go out to meet the preceptor and receive his bowl and robe. He should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.5: If the robe is moist, he should sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.6: He should fold the robe, offsetting the edges by seven centimeters,
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.7: so that the fold doesn’t become worn.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.8: He should place the belt in the fold.
pli-tv-kd1:25.10.9: If there is almsfood and his preceptor wants to eat, the student should give him water and then the almsfood.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.1: He should ask his preceptor if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.2: When the preceptor has eaten, the student should give him water and receive his bowl. Holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it. He should then dry it and sun it for a short while, but he shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.3: The student should put away the robe and bowl.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.4: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.5: He shouldn’t put the bowl away on the bare floor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.6: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.7: When the preceptor has gotten up, the student should put away the seat and also the foot stool, the foot scraper, and the water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd1:25.11.8: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.1: If the preceptor wants to bathe, the student should prepare a bath.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.2: If he wants a cold bath, he should prepare that;
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.3: if he wants a hot bath, he should prepare that.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.4: If the preceptor wants to take a sauna, the student should knead bath powder, moisten the clay, take a sauna bench, and follow behind his preceptor. After giving the preceptor the sauna bench, receiving his robe, and putting it aside, he should give him the bath powder and the clay.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.5: If he’s able, he should enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd1:25.12.6: When entering the sauna, he should smear his face with clay, cover himself front and back, and then enter.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.1: He shouldn’t sit encroaching on the senior monks,
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.2: and he shouldn’t block the junior monks from getting a seat.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.3: While in the sauna, he should do services for his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.4: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna bench, cover himself front and back, and then leave.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.5: He should also do services for his preceptor in the water.
pli-tv-kd1:25.13.6: When he has bathed, he should be the first to come out. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his preceptor’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe. Taking the sauna bench, he should be the first to return. He should prepare a seat, and also set out a foot stool, a foot scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should ask his preceptor if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.1: If the preceptor wants him to recite, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.2: If the preceptor wants to question him, he should be questioned.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.3: If the dwelling where the preceptor is staying is dirty, the student should clean it if he’s able.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.4: When he’s cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.5: He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.14.6: He should take out the mattress and the pillow and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.1: Holding the bed low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.2: Holding the bench low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.3: He should take out the bed supports and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.4: He should take out the spittoon and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.5: He should take out the leaning board and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.6: After taking note of its position, he should take out the floor cover and put it aside.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.7: If the dwelling has cobwebs, he should first remove them from the ceiling cloth, and he should then wipe the windows and the corners of the room.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.8: If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.9: If the floor has been treated with a black finish and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.10: If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it,
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.11: while trying to avoid stirring up dust.
pli-tv-kd1:25.15.12: He should look out for any trash and discard it.

pli-tv-kd1:25.16.3: He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back as before.

pli-tv-kd1:25.16.6: He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back as before.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.7: He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd1:25.16.8: He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.

pli-tv-kd1:32.1.1: At that time there were preceptors who went away, disrobed, died, or joined another faction, and as a result their students were not being instructed.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.2: When walking for almsfood, they were shabbily dressed and improper in appearance.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.3: While people were eating, they held out their almsbowls to receive leftovers, even right over their food, whether it was cooked or fresh food, delicacies or drinks.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.4: They ate bean curry and rice that they themselves had asked for,

pli-tv-kd1:32.1.15: After rebuking them, the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.17: The teacher should think of his pupil as a son and the pupil his teacher as a father.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.18: In this way they will respect, esteem, and be considerate toward each other, and they will grow and reach greatness on this spiritual path.
pli-tv-kd1:32.1.19: You should live with formal support for ten years. And I allow a monk of ten years’ seniority to give such support.
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.1: A teacher should be chosen like this:
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.2: After putting his upper robe over one shoulder, a pupil should pay respect at the feet of a potential teacher. He should then squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say,
pli-tv-kd1:32.2.3: ‘Venerable, please be my teacher. I wish to live with formal support from you.’

pli-tv-kd1:32.2.7: If the other doesn’t convey this by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then a teacher hasn’t been chosen.

pli-tv-kd1:33.1.70: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.71: If dusty winds are blowing from the east, he should close the windows on the eastern side.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.72: If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the western side.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.73: If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side.

pli-tv-kd1:33.1.75: If the weather is cold, he should open the windows during the day and close them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.76: If the weather is hot, he should close the windows during the day and open them at night.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.77: If the yard is dirty, he should sweep it.

pli-tv-kd1:33.1.79: If the assembly hall is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.80: If the water-boiling shed is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.81: If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.

pli-tv-kd1:33.1.84: If there is no water in the rinsing pot, he should fill it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.85: If the pupil becomes discontent with the spiritual life, the teacher should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.86: If the pupil becomes anxious, the teacher should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.87: If the pupil has wrong view, the teacher should make him give it up or have someone else do it, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.88: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.89: the teacher should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.90: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.91: the teacher should try to get the Sangha to do it.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.92: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves the trial period,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.93: the teacher should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.94: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.95: the teacher should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.96: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his pupil—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.97: the teacher should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.98: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his pupil—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.99: the teacher should help the pupil conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try to get the Sangha to lift that procedure.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.100: If the pupil’s robe needs washing, the teacher should show him how to do it,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.101: or he should make an effort to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.102: If the pupil needs a robe, the teacher should show him how to make one,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.103: or he should make an effort to get one made.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.104: If the pupil needs dye, the teacher should show him how to make it,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.105: or he should make an effort to get it made.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.106: If the pupil’s robe needs dyeing, the teacher should show him how to do it,
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.107: or he should make an effort to get it done.
pli-tv-kd1:33.1.108: When he’s dyeing the robe, he should carefully and repeatedly turn it over, and he shouldn’t go away while it’s still dripping.

pli-tv-kd1:34.1.1: On a later occasion the pupils did not conduct themselves properly toward their teachers. …
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.2: They told the Buddha what had happened. …
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.3: “A pupil should conduct himself properly toward his teacher.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.4: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.5: They still did not conduct themselves properly.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.6: They told the Buddha what had happened. …
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.7: “You should dismiss one who doesn’t conduct himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.8: And this is how he should be dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.9: If the teacher conveys the following by body, by speech, or by body and speech: ‘I dismiss you;’ ‘Don’t come back here;’ ‘Remove your bowl and robe;’ or, ‘You shouldn’t attend on me’—
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.10: then the pupil has been dismissed.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.11: If he doesn’t convey this by body, by speech, or by body and speech, then the pupil hasn’t been dismissed.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.12: Pupils who had been dismissed did not ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.15: They still did not ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.17: “One who has been dismissed should ask for forgiveness.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.18: If he doesn’t, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.19: Teachers who were asked for forgiveness did not forgive.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.23: The pupils left, disrobed, and joined the monastics of other religions.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.25: “When asked for forgiveness, you should forgive.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.26: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.27: Teachers dismissed pupils who were conducting themselves properly and did not dismiss those who were not.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.29: “You should not dismiss someone who is conducting himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.30: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.31: And you should dismiss someone who isn’t conducting himself properly.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.32: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.33: If a pupil has five qualities, he should be dismissed:

pli-tv-kd1:34.1.39: If a pupil has five qualities, he deserves to be dismissed:

pli-tv-kd1:34.1.46: The pupil doesn’t have much affection for his teacher; he doesn’t have much confidence in his teacher; he doesn’t have much conscience toward his teacher; he doesn’t have much respect for his teacher; he hasn’t developed his mind much under his teacher.

pli-tv-kd1:34.1.49: The pupil has much affection for his teacher; he has much confidence in his teacher; he has much conscience toward his teacher; he has much respect for his teacher; he has developed his mind much under his teacher.”
pli-tv-kd1:34.1.51: Asking for forgiveness when dismissed is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.1: Then, once they had ten years of seniority, ignorant and incompetent monks gave formal support.
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.2: As a result there were ignorant teachers with knowledgeable pupils,
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.5: and foolish teachers with wise pupils.
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.6: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.7: “How can ignorant and incompetent monks give formal support, just because they have ten years of seniority?
pli-tv-kd1:35.1.8: There are ignorant teachers with knowledgeable pupils, incompetent teachers with competent pupils, uneducated teachers with learned pupils, and foolish teachers with wise pupils.”
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.1: They told the Buddha what had happened. …
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.2: “Is it true, monks, that this is happening?”
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.8: He then gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.9: “An ignorant and incompetent monk should not give formal support.
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.10: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.11: I allow a competent and capable monk who has ten or more years of seniority to give formal support.”
pli-tv-kd1:35.2.12: The section on the ignorant and incompetent is finished.
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.0: 22. Discussion of the ending of formal support
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.1: At that time there were preceptors and teachers who went away, disrobed, died, or joined another faction, but their pupils did not know about the ending of support.
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.3: “There are these five reasons why the formal support from a preceptor comes to an end:
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.4: the preceptor goes away; the preceptor disrobes; the preceptor dies; the preceptor joins another faction; or the preceptor orders it.
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.6: There are these six reasons why the formal support from a teacher comes to an end:
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.7: the teacher goes away; the teacher disrobes; the teacher dies; the teacher joins another faction; the teacher orders it; or one is reunited with one’s preceptor.”
pli-tv-kd1:36.1.9: The discussion of the ending of formal support is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:38.1.0: 25. Discussion on those who have been monastics of another religion
pli-tv-kd1:38.1.1: Soon afterwards he who had been a monastic of another religion, and who had returned to that religious community after refuting his preceptor,
pli-tv-kd1:38.1.2: came back to the monks and asked for the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:38.1.4: “Monks, when someone who has been a monastic of another religion refutes his preceptor after being legitimately corrected by him and then returns to that religion, but then comes back from that religious community once more, he should not be given the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd1:38.1.5: Anyone else who has been a monastic of another religion, and who wants the going forth and the full ordination on this spiritual path, should be given four months of probation.
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.1: And it should be given like this.
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.2: First he should shave off his hair and beard and put on the ocher robes. He should then put his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the monks, squat on his heels, and raise his joined palms. He should then be told to say this:
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.3: ‘I go for refuge to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.4: I go for refuge to the Teaching,
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.5: I go for refuge to the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.6: For the second time I go for refuge to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.7: For the second time I go for refuge to the Teaching,
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.8: For the second time I go for refuge to the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.9: For the third time I go for refuge to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.10: For the third time I go for refuge to the Teaching,
pli-tv-kd1:38.2.11: For the third time I go for refuge to the Sangha.’
pli-tv-kd1:38.3.1: Then, after approaching the Sangha, he who had been a monastic of another religion should put his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the monks, squat on his heels, and raise his joined palms. He should then say this:
pli-tv-kd1:38.3.2: ‘Venerables, I have been a monastic of another religion, and I wish for the full ordination on this spiritual path.
pli-tv-kd1:38.3.3: I ask the Sangha for four months of probation.’
pli-tv-kd1:38.3.4: And he should ask a second
pli-tv-kd1:38.3.6: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd1:38.3.7: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd1:38.3.8: So-and-so, who has been a monastic of another religion, wants the full ordination on this spiritual path.

pli-tv-kd1:78.2.3: “When you have given the full ordination to someone, you should give him a companion and point out the four things not to be done:
pli-tv-kd1:78.2.4: A monk who is fully ordained should not have sexual intercourse, even with an animal.

pli-tv-kd1:78.3.1: A monk who is fully ordained should not steal, even a straw.
pli-tv-kd1:78.3.2: If he steals a pāda coin, the worth of a pāda, or more than a pāda, he’s not an ascetic, not a Sakyan monastic.
pli-tv-kd1:78.3.3: Just as a fallen, withered leaf is incapable of becoming green again,

pli-tv-kd1:78.4.1: A monk who is fully ordained should not intentionally kill a living being, even a small insect.
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.2: If he intentionally kills a human being, even causing an abortion, he’s not an ascetic, not a Sakyan monastic.
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.3: Just as an ordinary stone that has broken in half cannot be put back together again,
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.4: so too is a monk who has intentionally killed a human being not an ascetic, not a Sakyan monastic.
pli-tv-kd1:78.4.5: You shouldn’t do this for as long as you live.
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.1: A monk who is fully ordained should not claim a superhuman quality, even just saying, ‘I delight in solitude.’
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.2: If, because he has bad desires and is overcome by desire, he claims to have a non-existent superhuman quality—whether absorption, release, stillness, attainment, path, or fruit—he’s not an ascetic, not a Sakyan monastic.
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.3: Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth,
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.4: so too is a monk with bad desires, overcome by desire, who claims to have non-existent superhuman quality not an ascetic, not a Sakyan monastic.
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.5: You shouldn’t do this for as long as you live.”
pli-tv-kd1:78.5.6: The four things not to be done are finished.
